posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28018786
Success is the product of failure. No matter how much you fail, the object is the attempt and the lessons you learn. If you're trying and not finding ways to improve, that's one thing, but so long as you can learn from an experience then there was no failure. In fact, seeking success as the end is a mistake in itself, the real value comes from the experience and the lessons learned from the attempt. Rudyard Kipling writes in his poem "If": "If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster
And treat those two impostors just the same;"
Meaning that your success or failure is immaterial to the attempt, to your striving, and are both fleeting. Instead of being hung up on how you've failed, or pining for the fruits of your labor, let the labor be its own fruit, let becoming more self-assured be the end you seek. No finely crafted sword became honed without first being drenched in fire, then quenched, and fired again, then beaten by the hammer, and cut by the wheel, for these trials were necessary to form its sharp edge, and strengthen its blade. Embrace the trials you face, don't let the lessons slip past you, and don't let the lies of failure or success fool you into the idea that there's a final conclusion you'll someday find. So long as you're alive you'll be trying, and failing, and learning, and the occasional success only exists as a result of this process, not as its object. The process and how it will temper you is the real reward.

Since I left highschool in 2012 I spent almost every day smoking weed and skateboarding, then later on just going to work during the day, then driving my van to the airport and smoking weed there until bedtime.
I would hang out with friends and smoke weed, basically all I did was waste time and smoke weed. I was completely distracted in life. Was supposed to go to Uni and attend classes but instead I decided to smoke weed and not go because I was too high.
By the end of it I was just working and smoking every night and not even seeing my friends until the weekends. Must have spent over $10,000 or more on weed during those years.

I did this for about 8 years straight. Life just blew right past me.

Got the anxiety and panic attacks. Sobriety eventually fixes this.

What I've found over the years is when you smoke weed 24/7 it gives you just enough happiness or whatever to be satisfied with being a loser. It's a mental load that totally distracts you from the fact that you aren't doing anything.
Life without weed can seem meaningless because of the habit. You get hooked on the escape.

If you stop cold turkey you will find out very quick that you are just filling a gap in your life and avoiding any real path worth taking. You'll quickly start having to come up with things to keep you occupied (normie life)

I only just realised this after years of getting high. I was distracted from the fact I was letting my life go downhill.

Things like having a job, moving up in your career, getting skilled, buying a place, having a family and kids are all remedies for being a loser. They give your life purpose and meaning. They also make you a respectable person. (status)

The point of life is to search and find personal meaning. It is a journey and so far it has lead you here. Look deep inside and see where your heart leads you. Start by doing all those things you said you wanted to do. Make a bucket list. etc

Never too late to change your direction.

>>28021779
Honestly you should try reading up on logotherapy and existential psychology, Man's Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl.

I'm pretty much in the same boat as you right now except I have the solution, which really is to just pursue meaningful activities. Learn a new skill, something you've always wanted to learn, finish a project you've been drafting for way too long, whatever. As far as other nuance goes: What's happening is you've burned out on sensual indulgence and it's no longer this exciting reward but has instead become a baseline of comfort. At some point things stopped being a pleasure when you did them, and started being a pain when you didn't. Take video games for example, you say yourself you get no real joy from them but you continue to play them, why? I'm assuming it's because you need that distraction just to feel comfortable.

The only solution is to understand these facts and keep a focus towards trying to do things that are meaningful rather than just overindulge in life's pleasures until they're no longer pleasurable. It is obviously very possible for you to be able to enjoy sex and video games once more, you just need to learn these lessons and make them things you do *only* because they're pleasurable, and never because you're just bored. Also if symptoms persist you might need to be medicated for depression.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Small steps anon. There's no point in living 24 hours of being miserable when you know your life is already on a slow but certain descent. Take one hour out of that miserable cycle and do something productive. The key here is to do something not necessarily what you'd want the most for yourself in that moment, but to choose something that is productive enough that it betters your life in a small way. This could be taking out the trash, or doing a chore that you've been putting off. Until that hour is over, make the most out of it by stretching your body, doing some workouts -- do anything that will make the rest of the 23 hours just slightly better -- this means sitting down for a few minutes to write a plan for what you're going to do for the rest of the day, or to reflect on all you've done today and all you plan to do tomorrow, is also productive. You decide what is important to do. Use that time you set aside to do something productive to ease your biggest worry, maybe, see a doctor.

Throughout your journey you're going to have people telling you what to do. They will give you purpose and direction through god or some incomprehensible idea that they believe you should experience in order to "become better", but it doesn't seem like you're that type of person. Perhaps an ascetic approach will do you some good. You are being tempered by the vagaries of your journey. Our definition of happiness and how it is attained, or contented, will continue to change as we go through life. My point in all this is, perhaps it's time to seek inward.

posts.sub: Extreme life changing decision I have into a week to decide
posts.com:
I’m beyond lost and I really need advice.

I’m 28, I left school to work in marketing. I was fired in July of 2018 and haven’t been able to find real work since. 2019 I worked for my family’s business; which has been depressing, underpaying, and taken a major toll on my mental health, but it has kept a substantial gap off my resume.
I apply to at least 10 jobs a day every day, I get LinkedIn and indeed alerts daily and I regularly check Craigslist. If it’s a job I am even remotely qualified for, I apply. I get Nothing. Not even interviews. Even a fucking Dennys ghosted my application this year.
So I figured a degree might help and applied to several schools. By some weird twist of luck, the only school that accepted me was in Tokyo. Fast forward a few months and I now have a Japanese visa, classes start January 4th, but I am allowed to begin remotely.
I made a trip to Tokyo in early December to get an apartment and have internet set up. But I don’t know if I can go through with all of this.

The cost of getting to Japan with my computer and monitors will be high, I have to figure out how to sell my car, which I currently owe $24k on, which will likely be a loss, I have $1600 in debt from unexpected expenses last month that I have 6 months to pay off before getting charged interest, and that’s just some of the issues.
With this visa, I’ll only be allowed to work 28 hours a week, and I need at least $1500 to afford the $900 room expenses, $300-$400 for food, and then have some left over to pay down said debt.
I’ve been applying to jobs, but same as always, no replies and no interview. It also does not help that I do not speak Japanese very well, and the school has not offered much in the way of work either.

Should I take the extreme risk, accrue $25k in student debt, and try this in exchange for freedom and a chance at finding work, or stay at home and hope my situation changes?

Well fella, there's one thing I can tell you is certain about your situation in spite of all the unknowns: sitting around and waiting for change is the surest way of it never coming. You're making a move, a move you think has a future in it, a risk to be sure, but a risk made in the name of doing something you think is worth doing. I can tell you that, no matter the result, failure or success, or somewhere in between, fighting and trying for something you think is worthwhile will never be wrong. My mom used to tell me something I never believed growing up, and it was: "we'll figure it out, we'll make it work", and I always thought that was just a coping mechanism for the hardships we faced, but getting older I only find it to be more true every year. You can find a million reasons not to do something if you want to, but what we're so often bereft of is reasons TO do something, and once you find something you really want to do, think should be done, and believe in yourself to do, then everything else is just a problem to solve so that you can. You can find work if you try. You can get over the debt if you try. You might not know just how yet, but if you want what you're trying for, you'll figure it out, you'll make it work.


The only thing you'll regret at the end of the day is doing nothing, not trying, not taking a chance on yourself. Change comes from you, so make it happen.

Let's look at why Bitcoin failed: The main reason is because its only value was in its fungibility - it was redundant from the outset, and not in a good 'two is one' kind of way, but in a bad 'this requires the energy that sustains entire populations to produce' kind of way. If the only reason something is valuable is because you can sell it for USD then it really only speaks to the value of USD.

But even that value is questionable since, realistically, USD is just a less abstracted form of Bitcoin. Money has value inasmuch as it's an effective medium of exchange, and USD tends to be that. But the only reason USD has this power is because we all agree it does, it's used as a reserve currency, it's often backed by drilling contracts with other nations.

That's value though. Value is hard enough to talk objectively about, but here we're talking about "importance" which, to me, seems necessarily subjective. My dog is more important to me than the ~$50,000 worth of assets I have, which I am, in fact, highly dubious about since I grew up in the eighties and nineties and it wasn't homeless people jumping off the tops of wall street buildings during black Monday. I read a lot, I've read Gray's Anatomy for example, I'm not a psycho, I have no real inclination to do this, but it seems to me my knowledge about human anatomy is more important, and would be more important to others, because in a pinch I can just go around to yuppie bars, getting one of these soulless white collar criminals drunk, and trying to harvest their organs. Hearts are worth millions of dollars on the Indonesian black market, I'm sure I could easily arrange for a smuggler to be brought to Australia for collection in anticipation.

I'm not really criticising your own answer, afterall I've just used money to measure the reason my knowledge and skills are important to me, but to say that makes it 'the most important thing'? It seems like if I had that attitude, I'd be the guy losing his organs.

I for some time had something very similar to you, I was constantly reinstalling OS and programs because I felt that I had gotten some shit on my computer from somewhere, even though the probability of that was close to zero. Minor stuff has been like checking alarms a shitton so I don't sleep in, but I think the two I mentioned before are the biggest pains for me. Convincing myself that a thought is absurd is only possible when the thought is already weak and easy to push over. I don't have a really good way to put it, but it didn't work when my OCD was really bad

posts.com:
This is my personal experience after finding a long term girlfriend for the first time about a year ago.

Start working out, for a testosterone boost if nothing else. Always trying to improve your looks never hurts.

Stop seeking approval from others, embrace who you are and learn to love yourself. If you don't love yourself, then there will be no room for you to love someone else.

Access and feel your emotions as they come. Often those who are never gf have tucked away their sadness in order to protect themselves, but you won't have the yearning to fall in love if you never feel lonely. There is some underlying psychological motivation produced by the negative stimulus of being sad about being lonely. This includes not smoking weed, or at least it did for me personally.

Make sure you are exposing yourself to opportunities to meet people, however that may be; sports, school, hobby, board game club, anything. You won't find anyone if there is no potential supply pool. (dating apps are probably the worst place to meet people, they only make you more desperate, see next point)

Lastly, and maybe most importantly, stop looking for a girlfriend. Most relationships occur naturally and unintentionally. You can't choose to love someone, it just happens. Whenever you put yourself in a position to meet people, tell yourself that you just want to make friends, and that's it. Ignore every thought about "I want to date her" and just focus on making friends, males included. This can be the hardest step, but it is critical.

Dead-simple option is investing in a market-index type fund, where your investment and thus risk is spread amongst top companies in various sectors. You put it in, let it roll, add to it, and over time your money is making money then that money makes money, like a cage full of horny rodents. Bonus points if you put it in a 401k or Roth IRA so you don't have to fork over high taxes for capital gains and you get to retire someday with a nestegg. You could also juggle liabilities secured by your portfolio but that's mega-rich stuff afaik.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28021992
>5 year strategy
Put it in a bank account with at least 4% interest.
That's a free $4,000 a year plus compounding.
>10 year strategy
Blue chip with 20 - 30% returns over previous decades.
>15+ year strategy
Have a blue chip you like, but also get into the habit of reading white papers. Invest dividends from the blue chips into either promising pink sheets (usually STEM related, pharmaceuticals, bioengineering, IT) or undervalued exchange shares (usually mining companies that are in exploratory stages, or retail businesses, not often banking and finance for obvious reasons, though they will often be blue chips).

hi other human.
i'm also alone.
i'm also sober.
it's not so bad,
tomorrow will be tomorrow,
today was today.
it's another night.

in the last two years I tried to kill myself multiple times. was hospitalized for many attempts - after the attempts or during the effects of the attempts. both psychiatric and non.

i was medicated. at a time, it was needed. when it wasn't necessary, i took my sweet ass time and weaned off of it.

i've struggled with alcoholism for the last 18 years. and drug addiction.

but i look at that differently now. if i relapse, so be it. I ride it out. if I can't handle it, I tell a doctor I need librium or valium, and then I stop.

I've medically detoxed in the ER from alcohol about 20 times. I've done twice as many detoxes at home with librium or valium tapers. i've been in patient rehab and detox numerous times long ago. never worked.

what changed for me with drinking: over time the reward mechanism failed to outweigh the consequence mechanism.

when it wasn't like that, it was hard. nothing could have prevented me from drinking. so i understand your struggle. it's internal.

i once had FIVE YEARS sober and clean. there wasn't a day I didn't want to drink.

but now, i have drank maybe 20 days total in the last year and a half. and I probably only thought about drinking on those 20 days.

as for the depression. fuck, it's so hard to explain.

you didn't ask but i'm telling you cause it may help

g-d. purpose. meaning. absurdity. nature. i made a friend. time. taking care of me = after i found out what it meant to take care of me.

getting off bad meds like antipsychotics, and on good meds like suboxone. cut out drugs, even weed.

sleep. healthy sleep.

EXERCISE. every day 60-90 min lifting.

being alone can be hard sometimes. especially since my recent psychotic depression was due to existential loneliness - but oddly it was being alone that saved me from myself.

happy new years

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28019247
>Because marriage is an artifical social construct.
The entirety of a society is, by definition. The whole framework of laws and social norms that we live in is all "constructed", but that doesn't mean these constructions are without use or moral importance.

Marriage as an institution is an eminently useful one. It both makes the meaning of commitment clear and consistent to all, and allows for the enforcement of commitment on that basis. Without this, all you have is endless posturing. Millions upon millions of people jerking themselves off over their own defined "meaning" with absolutely no way to be sure of what anyone else even means, let alone put their own ideas into practice.

> I'm all for monogamy but waiting until marriage is absolute garbage
Pick one. If you want to spend your life with one person, who also solely devotes themselves to you, waiting until marriage is by far the best way to achieve this, not just for you but across society. Marriage gives people a road map to follow, and a guardrail to protect themselves if something goes wrong. That's the idea of "commitment". If you don't care about formal commitment, then you necessarily accept the much greater chance of nonmonogamy.

> before doing something that's a BASIC HUMAN NEED
Sex on demand isn't a need, but even if we concede in some vague sense that sex is a "need", something being a need doesn't mean any constraints on it are wrong or even bad ideas. For example, food is a basic need, but in a crisis, rationing is not only justified but demonstrably better than letting people gorge themselves.
More generally, a society arguably is the collection of relationships between people and the rules governing those relationships. Any society has a vested interest in regulating itself, which includes setting conditions on the ways people relate to each other. Sex is a pretty fundamental relationship to any society, and this means it's MORE important to regulate it, not less.

posts.sub: How can I be more superficial and fun?
posts.com:
I've been consumed by reading, thinking, and trying to find answers to politics, philosophy, religion, the meaning of life, etc., for the past few years. Now I'm done because I realized that I'm never going to find clean cut answers to those questions, so I found an answer that works for me and cut my losses. Unfortunately, I put almost all my other hobbies and interests on hold, and now I've become way too boring, serious, and unimaginative of a person (when I was already pretty serious to begin).

So, how can I be more superficial, light-hearted and fun? It seems like even something as simple as making jokes, looking forward to the next movie, playing a character, etc., has a lot of depth to it, even if it's all appearances. I know that practice makes perfect, but it's one of those things that I have no idea where to begin working on because it's so alien to me now. It's like I almost got rid of my entire personality for this quest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28006809
Just enjoy fun stuff. That's it.
Preferably watch comedy stuff like Monty Python or The Office, as getting into other serious stuff like The Sopranos will still make you a boring guy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28006809
Don't refer to these people as superficial please.
You're not even that deep, everyone goes through the same shit, but manifests it in completely different ways.
It's just a phase of growing up, you'll need to adapt later in life, since I assume that you're pretty young. You don't need to fake anything, just get some friends and hang out with them, and learn that life isn't too serious.
Try to learn what's enjoyable and what's not, and how to enjoy it yourself, but there's no need to call the mundane things superficial, or feel superior to people who enjoy them. Just be open minded.

>>28015068
Don't worry, I've been exploring the faith for a while now (redoubled my efforts lately), and I appreciate the extra nudge. I've been reading the Bible, thinking about it and trying to apply it to my life, and looking for thoughtful Biblical commentary wherever I could find it.

The funny thing is that even religion can lead astray. I realized that a big portion of my search for God was completely misguided (and thus my faith stunted) because I thought religion had to do with being a good person. Then it became a quest of finding the perfect philosophy, the perfect mysticism, the perfect politics, etc., to repair an utterly broken society. It was such a prideful, silly, and vain venture, even if society forces you to care about the impossible. No, you don't have to be religious to be a good person, at least in the eyes of society. You can always be "good enough" and carve out your rewards later. Society is about getting our needs met, the bare minimums, and rarely does it rise above that standard (because we simply don't *have* to).

The whole point of Christ's revelation is that everything, EVERYTHING worldly falls short of God, that Christ died for our sins, and Christ's sacrifice enables us to embrace the gift of eternal life. In that moment, He opened the way for us to follow in His footsteps, to surrender to the radical freedom (and the subsequent radical responsibility) of living life in communion with God, to excel beyond what the moral standards of the day call for and to embody God's love on Earth with what little time I have in this world. I realized that I could never be the perfect person I wanted to be in the eyes of God, yet nothing else short of that flame would ever satisfy me either. I've been hungering for that realization so I could imbibe it until it consumed every fiber of my being.

That's the reason why I "cut my losses" in the OP btw lol. It left me much happier, understanding my place in the universe and accepting it.

You seem to have a good understanding of what God did for us in Christ, and how we can never be good enough on our own.
You're also right about how religion leads astray, because all religions are false. I don't consider biblical Christianity a religion, it is more like just the only perfect way of life. The only way to be free from the wickedness of this world.

If you really want to see the power of God though, and the truth of Jesus Christ, you have to actually believe it and do what He told us to do. So repenting and getting baptized in Jesus' name is mandatory, and you have to actually believe that receiving the Holy Spirit is real or else you'll never receive Him.

It also helps to believe the truth about the nature of God. He is one person, not three. Jesus said that the Father is the only true God (John 17:3), and the scripture says that in Him (Jesus Christ) dwells all the fullness of the Godhead (deity) bodily (Colossians 2:8-9). So Jesus Christ is the incarnation of God, not a second co-eternal, co-equal person. Also, since we know that the only true God is the Father, and that the Father is Holy (Leviticus 19:2), and that He is a spirit (John 4:24), we can therefore deduce that the Holy Spirit is the Spirit of the one true God, not a third co-equal, co-eternal person. So there is one God, who is one person.

You don't have to understand that to have a true faith, but it is really important that you know what God you're serving. If you don't get it or don't agree about that particular point, don't let that stop you from continuing to seek God in spirit and in truth.

Like I said, I did all the philosophy stuff, searching for the truth/meaning of life over the last nearly 3 years. I eventually came to the intellectual conclusion that Christianity must be true but it wasn't until I started taking the word of God at face value that I began to experience true freedom.

Anyway, just keep seeking bro. God bless you.

Good morning, /adv/. I've been running an experiment this year regarding interacting with strangers. The idea was to compliment five strangers a week. If a conversation occurred organically, I would continue it. If not, I would tell them to have a nice day.

TL;DR: Conquer anxiety by directly addressing it, realize you have more to gain than lose, be polite, expect nothing, receive gracefully. People are more likely to want to interact with you then you think. Build confidence and the world
opens up to you.

This is week 52 of the year, that means I've had 260 experiences with completely new people. Of all of those experiences, two were negative, three were neutral, and 255 have been positive. 202 interactions have been with women, the rest with men.

On location - All of these notes are from approaching people in parks, coffee shops, concerts, and on the street in metro areas. There is very little to lose in the aforementioned locations. At church, work, or other large social gatherings that you frequent, the stakes are a little higher but worst case, something gets awkward and it blows over in a week or two. Always be respectful and give people space if it does go sour.

On approach - I tend to first make eye contact with someone, then smile real big, and begin conversation with 'excuse me' or 'pardon me' and then give a simple compliment. They usually say thank you, then they'll chitchat, and then I'll walk away with a 'have a nice day'. My compliments are never on crass physical features but instead tend to be on things the person have put effort into. I would recommend against approaching someone from behind. It tends to spook people, no matter how attractive you are, and leads to negative experiences.

Continued.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On expectations - My objective with any of these interactions is simply pay a compliment, brighten someone's day, and continue about my walk/business. If conversation naturally happens, I engage in it. If a person is interested in you, this will happen very organically. You'll be surprised at how easy conversation gets after a while of talking to strangers. If this continues for a bit and the person I'm speaking to is an attractive woman, I tell her I need to go and get her number. In this scenario, it's best to leave on a high note to keep a person wanting more.

On energy - People, if in a largely neutral state, will mirror whatever energy you present to them. If you approach a person while nervous, angry, fearful, etc., they will mimic that back to you. That will set the tone and course of your conversation. Conversely, if you approach with a big smile, open body language, and polite conversation, they will mirror it as well. This works in almost all scenarios. Hasn't backfired on me once.

Continued

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Results - I now know a ton of people around the city. I'm considered a regular at the parks I go to and now make convo with these folks reguarly. I've been invited to a few parties. I've asked 40 women for their numbers, gone on dates with 26 of them. I no longer use dating applications. Even the women that did not really match with me still approach me to make chitchat at parks/shops.

Me: Male, 30, 20-25% bodyfat, pretty average looking, 6'1, slightly thinning hair.

Pictures: Taken on a date with some girl who flew me to her city to hang out. I met her at a park and we dated for a few months.

I'm a virgin woman and always wanted to wait for marriage but the more I think about it the more I think it's not a good idea because sex and intimacy is the thing that separates a romantic relationship from a friendship. There are just so many ways we could be sexually incompatible, it's not as simple as people on here say that you can figure it out together just by putting in more effort and time, that's a pretty naive thought. It would be like marrying someone you never met and thinking you can make it work just by trying hard. I would like to think I would love my husband enough to stay with him even if we didn't have sex or feel satisfied by it, but I would eventually feel unloved and come to resent him. Waiting for marriage does not guarantee that we won't divorce due to sexual problems. So I think a better compromise is to wait for sex in a serious relationship, and treat marriage as less of a beginning for something but rather something that happens because we already feel married and sure we'll be together for the rest of our lives already.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28021138
You don’t consider your friends as potential spouses. You do in a relationship. That doesn’t require sex.

Sexual compatibility is also a meme. Don’t fall for the propaganda of hedonists—the vast majority of incompatibilities are addressed just as well, and arguably better by waiting until marriage and communicating decently:

Vast difference in sex drives? Those with extremely high drives are neither willing nor able to wait. Compare that to the trope of people having sex often initially, only for it to fall off later and for the couple to break up anyway after the higher-drive partner gets frustrated.
Disgusting fetishes are far more common among the hypersexual anyway, and even fetishists themselves emphasize how important it is to communicate preferences *before* forcing it on an unsuspecting partner.
And literal deformities are both vanishingly rare while also being best addressed by honesty. In the absolute worst case, you can tell at a glance, with no need to go further to be sure.

Anything less extreme than the above can be negotiated with good communication in the context of an already loving relationship (why else decide to spend your lives together?).

And then there’s the most important thing of them all: waiting until marriage is designed for monogamy, for having a unique, exclusive bond with your life partner. Those who wait factually divorce less and have happier marriages, even controlling for religion, so any supposed benefit to sexual compatibility of sex before marriage is clearly outweighed by the benefits of waiting. Giving up the best chance at the deepest intimacy possible to chase a phantom benefit is a downright horrible trade. Don’t give up on such a beautiful thing for so flimsy a reason.

Feminism has been a disaster, but it wouldn't have found the fuel it did if it weren't for the real wrongs committed by men. The existence of prostitution, spousal abuse without recourse, weak enforcement of anti-adultery provisions against men, and more all served to weaken men's claim to any kind of moral authority, and while feminism offered something even worse (make women equally immoral), it came packaged with a guarantee that women would be able to protect themselves from male misbehavior instead of relying wholly on the benevolence of men. It's not hard to see why a battered and disrespected woman would find the idea of increased personal control appealing, and you can hardly be surprised at people accepting a solution to their immediate problems without considering the consequences of it a century later.
